author: andschwa
body:
While we already have a package creation infrastructure, we're hearing new requirements for said packages, such as:
- [ ] Install multiple versions side-by-side, e.g. `/prefix/powershell_1`, `/prefix/powershell_2`, with the current desired version symlinked to `/prefix/powershell`
- [ ] Enable dynamic version choice over PSRP, looking up path for version in `/etc/powershell.conf`
- [x] Change prefix from `/usr/local` to `/opt/microsoft`

We can't move on these until we have concrete requirements.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
From: Wim Coekaerts:

> ... the binary and libraries and a bunch of ps1xml files are all in /usr/local/share/powershell. Would it make sense to separate them out in bin/ lib/ etc/ ? In fact, even though for ‘3rd party’ it’s typically a good idea to have things in /usr/local or so… at least in the old days, there’s also possibly /usr/ (like anything native) or /opt/Microsoft/ or so. This can be religious some times with some folks but I think a bit of a split of bin/lib would be good either way – location-wise usr/local/ is not bad but I am not sure if that’s typical any more.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
What's been implemented:

Linux now installs to `/opt/microsoft/powershell` (and OS X still installs to `/usr/local/share/powershell` because that's required).
